author: Dan Bloom
title: Firms 'named and shamed' for not paying minimum wage secretly underpaid 30,000 workers by another £1.8million
text:
News Firms 'named and shamed' for not paying minimum wage secretly underpaid 30,000 workers by another £1.8million The total is bigger than the sums ministers "named and shamed" in the first place - but this time, they aren't revealing who the 82 companies are Share Theresa May's officials will not be releasing the new list of firms (Photo: Adam Gerrard/Daily Mirror) Share Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Firms humiliated by the government for not paying minimum wage secretly underpaid more than 30,000 workers by a further £1.8m. 
The figures have been revealed after Tory ministers "named and shamed" 556 firms for paying their employees less than the legal rate. 
At the time the government trumped how the firms had collectively owed £1.4million to more than 17,000 workers. 
Now it admits 82 of those "named and shamed" firms underpaid a further £1.8million to 32,070 employees. 
But ministers are refusing to say who the firms were - despite claiming the naming scheme ensures "abuses will not go unpunished". Read More Debenhams and Peacocks among 360 firms named and shamed for failing to pay minimum wage 
That is because the wages were paid back to workers through a separate "self-correction" scheme. 
Financial Secretary to the Treasury Jane Ellison said: "For reasons of confidentiality, HMRC does not disclose information relating to the affairs of an individual or company." Firms rarely face prosecution for underpaying the minimum wage (Photo: Getty) 
Green Party co-leader Caroline Lucas, who obtained the figures, said that excuse was "unacceptable". 
She told the Mirror: "No financial penalties were imposed on those 82 employers in relation to that £1.8m of arrears. 
"In other words, large employers are paying penalties on only a small part of the arrears they are found by HMRC to owe to workers. 
"That is utterly unacceptable. Read More Full list of 360 employers named and shamed for failing to pay minimum wage 
“If the public are to have any confidence in the naming & shaming scheme, ministers must act to increase both transparency and accountability. 
"And they must extend both financial penalties and ‘naming & shaming’ itself to the arrears recovered under the self-correction mechanism.” 
High street giants were among those named amid a blaze of publicity in two separate lists in August 2016 and February 2017. Green co-leader Caroline Lucas said the new tally was "utterly unacceptable" (Photo: Getty) 
The first tranche of 197 firms were named for underpaying more than 1,600 workers to the tune of £465,291 - you can see the full list here. 
Ministers now say 22 of them repaid a further £410,967 in "self-correction" arrears to 1,574 workers. 
The second tranche of 359 firms were named for underpaying 15,520 workers to the tune of £995,233 - you can see the full list here. 
Ministers now say 60 of them repaid a further £1,435,419 in "self-correction" arrears to 30,946 workers. 
Since 2013 the government has named and shamed nearly all firms issued with a formal Notice of Underpayment (NOU), which carries penalties worth twice the unpaid wages up to £20,000 per worker. 
But government policy says firms can avoid receiving a NOU for wages that they "self-correct" through their own systems. 
In some cases a NOU may be issued for a small portion of underpaid wages, and a firm is then expected to "self-correct" the rest. 
"In all cases of self-correction HMRC ensures that the workers receive the money they are due," the policy document says. 
In January the Mirror revealed how not one of 700 firms named and shamed between 2013 and 2016 had been prosecuted. 
Labour peer Lord Beecham said at the time: "What a contrast between the approach to employers breaking the law and exploiting their workers and the sanctions regime applied ruthlessly to benefit claimants." 
Ms Lucas said "the worst offenders should certainly face criminal prosecution", but added: "The key is getting workers the money they deserve". Read More Not ONE firm 'named and shamed' for paying below minimum wage has been prosecuted, Tory minister says 
A Government spokesperson said: "Every worker in the UK is entitled to at least the national minimum or living wage and this government will ensure they get it. The Government is committed to making sure our economy works for everyone and that is why we are determined to further clamp down on bosses who short-change their workers. 
"In all cases of self-correction HMRC will take action to ensure that workers receive the money they are legally entitled to.” Like us on Facebook
